org.apache.freemarker.core.templateresolver.impl

Class DefaultTemplateNameFormat

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.freemarker.core.templateresolver.TemplateNameFormat
      • org.apache.freemarker.core.templateresolver.impl.DefaultTemplateNameFormat

  • public final class DefaultTemplateNameFormat
extends TemplateNameFormat
    The default Configuration.getTemplateNameFormat() template name format}. This defines a format where directories and file names in a path are separated with "/" (slash). "\" (backslash) is not allowed and causes MalformedTemplateNameException. Directory names "." and ".." are treated specially with the same meaning as in UN*X paths. Directory name "*" is treated as acquisition mark (see Configuration.getTemplate(String, Locale, Serializable, boolean)).

    The name may starts with scheme part, like in "classpath:com/example/bar.ftl" (scheme "classpath" and absolute path "com/example/bar.ftl") or "cms://example.com/foo.ftl" (scheme "cms" and absolute path "example.com/foo.ftl"). The scheme name before the ":" (colon) can't contain "/", and ":" can only be used for denoting the scheme, or else MalformedTemplateNameException is thrown. The scheme part can be separated either with "://" or just with ":" from the path, hence, myschme:/x is normalized to myschme:x, while myschme:///x is normalized to myschme://x, but myschme://x or myschme:/x aren't changed by normalization. It's up the TemplateLoader (to which the normalized names are passed) to decide which of these scheme separation conventions are accepted.

    Template names might end with /, like "foo/", and the presence or lack of the terminating "/" is significant. While their actual interpretation is up to the TemplateLoader, operations that manipulate template names assume that the last step refers to a "directory" as opposed to a "file" exactly if the terminating / is present. Except, the empty name is assumed to refer to the root "directory" (despite that it doesn't end with /).

    // is normalized to /, except of course if it's in the scheme name terminator. Like foo//bar///baaz.ftl is normalized to foo/bar/baaz.ftl. Hence 0 length step names aren't possible.

    Multiple consecutive "*" steps are normalized to one
